persona.name: Rajesh Kumar
persona.description: Rajesh is a 29-year-old knowledge modeler located in Bangalore, India. He holds a Master's degree in Information Science and has 6 years of experience working in the publishing industry, focusing on semantic annotation and metadata modeling. Rajesh has deep domain knowledge of fiction genres, including fantasy and science fiction, which he integrates into his ontology development work to ensure nuanced and culturally diverse representations. He is proficient with ontology editing tools like Protégé and has working knowledge of machine learning techniques to enhance ontology enrichment. Rajesh is an avid gamer and fantasy novel enthusiast, which informs his understanding of complex narrative structures and character development.

persona.name: Dr. Sophia Bennett
persona.description: Sophia is a 38-year-old ontology engineer based in Berlin, Germany. She holds a PhD in Computer Science with a specialization in Semantic Web technologies. With over 12 years of experience in developing domain ontologies, Sophia has worked extensively on cultural and literary knowledge representation projects. She is highly proficient in OWL, RDF, and SPARQL, and has a keen interest in integrating narrative theories into ontological models. Sophia is passionate about bridging the gap between literary scholarship and computational modeling, which allows her to offer unique insights into representing fiction through characters, events, and story arcs. Outside of work, she enjoys reading classic literature and experimenting with AI-driven storytelling tools.

She has 5 years of experience and is highly proficient in digital writing tools, virtual collaboration platforms, and narrative design software. persona.name: Prof. Amina Al-Farsi
persona.description: Prof. Amina Al-Farsi is a 58-year-old professor of narratology and semiotics at a university in Muscat, Oman. She has a background in linguistics and Middle Eastern studies, with a Ph.D. focused on narrative dynamics within oral storytelling traditions and written fiction. With over 30 years of teaching and research experience, Amina integrates traditional narrative analysis with modern theoretical frameworks. She has moderate technological proficiency but a strong grasp of digital humanities methods. Her interests lie in the intersection of oral and written narratives and how story arcs evolve in different media. Amina offers crucial insights into the ways cultural narrative forms shape fiction books and the role of storytelling in identity and memory.

Sophia combines her academic insights with strong interests in new media storytelling and interactive fiction.
